rendered_text:
1. [1 point] Select ALL that apply: Around 2007, the claim "Rails doesn't scale" was attributed to

    Twitter engineers, and the fact that Twitter later moved

    away from Rails was cited by some as evidence that the claim was true.

    Which of the following statements (there may be more than one) describe Raffi

    Krikorian's (Twitter Director of Engineering) views on this subject?

    1. Rails itself isn't the problem, but the original Ruby VM does have some performance problems that impede scaling for heavy server workloads.
    2. Rails itself isn't the problem, but the development processes typically used around Rails don't scale well to large teams.
    3. If you're building a startup and expect high volume, Raffi Krikorian would advise you to stay away from Ruby and Rails from the start.
    4. If Twitter had been architected as a service-oriented architecture from the start, they might have stayed on Ruby/Rails somewhat longer than they did.
json:
{   "answers": [     {       "answer_text": "Rails itself isn't the problem, but the original Ruby VM does have some performance problems that impede scaling for heavy server workloads.",       "correct": true,       "explanation": null     },     {       "answer_text": "Rails itself isn't the problem, but the development processes typically used around Rails don't scale well to large teams.",       "correct": true,       "explanation": null     },     {       "answer_text": "If you're building a startup and expect high volume, Raffi Krikorian would advise you to stay away from Ruby and Rails from the start.",       "correct": false,       "explanation": null     },     {       "answer_text": "If Twitter had been architected as a service-oriented architecture from the start, they might have stayed on Ruby/Rails somewhat longer than they did.",       "correct": true,       "explanation": null     }   ],   "points": 1,   "raw": null,   "name": null,   "question_tags": [    ],   "question_comment": "",   "question_text": "Around 2007, the claim "Rails doesn't scale"  was attributed to
Twitter engineers, and the fact that Twitter later moved
away from Rails was cited by some as evidence that the claim was true.
Which of the following statements (there may be more than one) describe Raffi
Krikorian's (Twitter Director of Engineering) views on this subject?",   "multiple": true,   "randomize": false,   "question_type": "SelectMultiple" }

rendered_text:
1. [1 point] Select ALL that apply: Which statements comparing Plan-and-Document (P&D) with

    Agile software engineering processes are true?

    1. The basic types of activities involved in software engineering are the same in P&D and Agile methodologies
    2. Because Agile tends to focus on small teams, it cannot be used effectively to build large systems.
    3. The Waterfall methodology involves the customer much more heavily at the beginning and end of the lifecycle, whereas the XP (extreme programming) methodology involves the customer throughout the lifecycle.
    4. The Spiral methodology combines elements of the waterfall model with intermediate prototypes.
json:
{   "answers": [     {       "answer_text": "The basic types of activities involved in software
            engineering are the same in P&D and Agile methodologies",       "correct": true,       "explanation": "
            True: requirements analysis, design, testing, development,
            deployment/delivery, and maintenance are all part of both
            P&D and Agile, but their interaction over the project
            lifetime differs between P&D and Agile.
            "     },     {       "answer_text": "Because Agile tends to focus on small teams, it cannot
                be used effectively to build large systems.",       "correct": false,       "explanation": "
            False: many Agile-developed small services can be connected
            together to form large services in a Service-Oriented Architecture.
            For example, Amazon.com is architected this way.
            "     },     {       "answer_text": "The Waterfall methodology involves the customer much more heavily at
            the beginning and end of the lifecycle, whereas the XP (extreme
            programming) methodology involves the customer throughout
            the lifecycle.",       "correct": true,       "explanation": "
            True: a basic tenet of XP is getting frequent feedback from
            the customer and using it to inform the next iteration of
            work.
            "     },     {       "answer_text": "The Spiral methodology combines elements of the waterfall model
            with intermediate prototypes.",       "correct": true,       "explanation": null     }   ],   "points": 1,   "raw": null,   "name": null,   "question_tags": [    ],   "question_comment": "",   "question_text": "Which statements comparing Plan-and-Document (P&D) with
            Agile software engineering processes are true?",   "multiple": true,   "randomize": false,   "question_type": "SelectMultiple" }

rendered_text:
1. [1 point] In an HTML5 document, what would be the best way to apply the same text-styling rules to several pieces of text that are scattered over the page and are part of different types of HTML elements (<p>, <span>, etc.)?

    1. Make sure all the elements to be styled have a common parent (ancestor) element
    2. Give all the elements to be styled the same "id" attribute value
    3. Give all the elements to be styled the same "class" attribute value
    4. Any of the above techniques would work
json: { "answers": [ { "answer_text": "Make sure all the elements to be styled have a common parent (ancestor) element", "correct": false, "explanation": "Even when this is possible, it isn't enough to be able to selectively pick out just the elements you want. Indeed, on a legal HTML 5 page, all the elements already have the common ancestor <body>." }, { "answer_text": "Give all the elements to be styled the same \"id\" attribute value", "correct": false, "explanation": "The \"id\" attribute value must be unique across all elements on a page." }, { "answer_text": "Give all the elements to be styled the same \"class\" attribute value", "correct": true, "explanation": "Since the same class can be applied to many elements, even if they are of different element types, it provides an easy way to apply a set of CSS style rules to many elements at once." }, { "answer_text": "Any of the above techniques would work", "correct": false, "explanation": null } ], "points": 1, "raw": true, "name": null, "question_tags": [ ], "question_comment": "", "question_text": "In an HTML5 document, what would be the best way to apply the same text-styling rules to several pieces of text that are scattered over the page and are part of different types of HTML elements (<p>, <span>, etc.)?", "multiple": false, "randomize": false, "question_type": "MultipleChoice" }

rendered_text:
1. [1 point] Consider the following Ruby class for a student with instance variables for first and last name, and an incomplete method for returning the student's full name: 

     class Student   attr_accessor :first, :last   def full_name      ____________   end  end
    Which of the following would be legal ways to fill in the blank so that the full_name method returns a student's full name (first followed by space followed by last)? You can assume first and last name are legal strings, and that '+' can be used to concatenate strings.

    1. @first + " " + @last
    2. self.first + " " + self.last
    3. Student.first + " " + Student.last
    4. "#{first} #{last}"
    5. self.@first + " " + self.@last
json:
{ "answers": [ { "answer_text": "@first + " " + @last", "correct": true, "explanation": "@first and @last are instance variables, so this statement works." }, { "answer_text": "self.first + " " + self.last", "correct": true, "explanation": "The first and last methods are created by the call to attr_accessor." }, { "answer_text": "Student.first + " " + Student.last", "correct": false, "explanation": "This would be correct if first and last were class ("static") methods, but they are instance methods." }, { "answer_text": ""#{first} #{last}"", "correct": true, "explanation": "Here first and last are resolved as method calls on self, though it's often clearer to include self explicitly." }, { "answer_text": "self.@first + " " + self.@last", "correct": false, "explanation": "a.b always means "Call method b on receiver a", but @first cannot be a legal Ruby method name." } ], "points": 1, "raw": true, "name": null, "question_tags": [ ], "question_comment": "", "question_text": " Consider the following Ruby class for a student with instance variables for first and last name, and an incomplete method for returning the student's full name: 
class Student
  attr_accessor :first, :last
  def full_name
     ____________
  end
 end
Which of the following would be legal ways to fill in the blank so that the full_name method returns a student's full name (first followed by space followed by last)? You can assume first and last name are legal strings, and that '+' can be used to concatenate strings. ", "multiple": false, "randomize": false, "question_type": "MultipleChoice" }

rendered_text:
1. [1 point] Select ALL that apply: Comparing plan-and-document vs. agile approaches to cost estimation, which statements are TRUE:

    1. Both try to identify and estimate the impact of possible risks
    2. Frequent iterations of the prototype are a risk-reduction tactic that is present in Agile but absent from P&D methodologies
    3. In both methodologies, nontechnical risks are more likely to jeopardize the schedule than technical risks.
    4. Both must deal with customers asking for changes after schedule is in place and project starts
json: {   "answers": [     {       "answer_text": "Both try to identify and estimate the impact of possible risks",       "correct": true,       "explanation": "Agile uses risk information to estimate the scope of a customer estimate, whereas P&D uses risk information up-front to adjust the schedule, but both methodologies take account of risk."     },     {       "answer_text": "Frequent iterations of the prototype are a risk-reduction tactic that is present in Agile but absent from P&D methodologies",       "correct": false,       "explanation": "Spiral and RUP incorporate frequent iteration as part of risk reduction."     },     {       "answer_text": "In both methodologies, nontechnical risks are more likely to jeopardize the schedule than technical risks.",       "correct": false,       "explanation": "In both methodologies, neither technical or nontechnical risks are inherently more serious than the other; either type could potentially have a serious impact on the schedule."     },     {       "answer_text": "Both must deal with customers asking for changes after schedule is in place and project starts",       "correct": true,       "explanation": null     }   ],   "points": 1,   "raw": null,   "name": null,   "question_tags": [    ],   "question_comment": "",   "question_text": "Comparing plan-and-document vs. agile approaches to cost estimation, which statements are TRUE:",   "multiple": true,   "randomize": false,   "question_type": "SelectMultiple" }

rendered_text:
1. [1 point] Consider the following Ruby code: 

     class Student   attr_reader :first, :last   def initialize(first, last)     @first = first     @last = last     @full = first + ' ' + last  end end
    Suppose from OUTSIDE the class we execute @student = Student.new('Armando','Fox'). Which of the following expressions will return this student's full name (first followed by space followed by last)?

    1. @student.first + " " + @student.last
    2. @student.full
    3. @student.@full
    4. Student.first + " " + Student.last
json:
{ "answers": [ { "answer_text": "@student.first + " " + @student.last", "correct": true, "explanation": "This works by using the accessors for first and last." }, { "answer_text": "@student.full", "correct": false, "explanation": "There is no accessor method defined for the @full instance variable." }, { "answer_text": "@student.@full", "correct": false, "explanation": "a.b always means call method b on object a, but @full is not a legal method name." }, { "answer_text": "Student.first + " " + Student.last", "correct": false, "explanation": "This would be correct if first and last were class ("static") methods, but they are instance methods." } ], "points": 1, "raw": true, "name": null, "question_tags": [ ], "question_comment": "", "question_text": " Consider the following Ruby code: 
class Student
  attr_reader :first, :last
  def initialize(first, last)
    @first = first
    @last = last
    @full = first + ' ' + last
 end
end
Suppose from OUTSIDE the class we execute @student = Student.new('Armando','Fox'). Which of the following expressions will return this student's full name (first followed by space followed by last)? ", "multiple": false, "randomize": false, "question_type": "MultipleChoice" }

1. [1 point] Which statement best reflects how Agile Scrum-based teams would prioritize and deliver User Stories?

    1. The Product Owner sets the number of points each story is worth
    2. The Project Manager sets the number of points each story is worth
    3. Anyone can work on a story and mark it Finished, but only the Product Owner can officially Deliver it to the customer
    4. Anyone can mark a story Delivered, but only the Product Owner can mark it as Accepted or Rejected
json: {   "answers": [     {       "answer_text": "The Product Owner sets the number of points each story is worth",       "correct": false,       "explanation": "The team typically votes or comes to group consensus on point values for stories."     },     {       "answer_text": "The Project Manager sets the number of points each story is worth",       "correct": false,       "explanation": "The team typically votes or comes to group consensus on point values for stories."     },     {       "answer_text": "Anyone can work on a story and mark it Finished, but only the Product Owner can officially Deliver it to the customer",       "correct": false,       "explanation": null     },     {       "answer_text": "Anyone can mark a story Delivered, but only the Product Owner can mark it as Accepted or Rejected",       "correct": true,       "explanation": null     }   ],   "points": 1,   "raw": null,   "name": null,   "question_tags": [    ],   "question_comment": "",   "question_text": "Which statement best reflects how Agile Scrum-based teams would prioritize and deliver User Stories?",   "multiple": false,   "randomize": false,   "question_type": "MultipleChoice" }

rendered_text:
1. [1 point] Assuming you are using the "deploy from master" methodology in your team, which of the following is NOT a good practice for adding code for a new feature?

    1. Fork, develop the feature on master of your own fork, and do a pull request
    2. Fork, develop the feature on another branch of your own fork, and do a pull request
    3. Create a branch on the main repo, develop on that branch, then merge the branch into master
    4. Develop directly on master if the feature only affects one or two files
json: {   "answers": [     {       "answer_text": "Fork, develop the feature on master of your own fork, and do a pull request",       "correct": false,       "explanation": "Since deployment is from the main repo's master branch and not your fork, it's OK to pollute your master branch."     },     {       "answer_text": "Fork, develop the feature on another branch of your own fork, and do a pull request",       "correct": false,       "explanation": null     },     {       "answer_text": "Create a branch on the main repo, develop on that branch, then merge the branch into master",       "correct": false,       "explanation": null     },     {       "answer_text": "Develop directly on master if the feature only affects one or two files",       "correct": true,       "explanation": "Never develop directly on whichever branch is the 'clean' branch that is safe to deploy.  By assumption, in this question that would be the master branch."     }   ],   "points": 1,   "raw": null,   "name": null,   "question_tags": [    ],   "question_comment": "",   "question_text": "Assuming you are using the \"deploy from master\" methodology in your team, which of the following is NOT a good practice for adding code for a new feature?",   "multiple": false,   "randomize": false,   "question_type": "MultipleChoice" }

    1. @student.first + " " + @student.last
    2. @student.full
    3. @student.@full
    4. Student.first + " " + Student.last

end
